citeinfo.title: Selected items from the Census of Agriculture at the county level for the conterminous United States, 1950-2012

descript.abstract:
This metadata report documents tabular data sets consisting of items from the Census of Agriculture. These data are a subset of items from county-level data (including state totals) for the conterminous United States covering the census reporting years (every five years, with adjustments for 1978 and 1982) beginning with the 1950 Census of Agriculture and ending with the 2012 Census of Agriculture. Historical (1950-1997) data were extracted from digital files obtained through the Intra-university Consortium on Political and Social Research (ICPSR). More current (1997-2012) data were extracted from the National Agriculture Statistical Service (NASS) Census Query Tool for the census years of 1997, 2002, 2007, and 2012. Most census reports contain item values from the prior census for comparison. At times these values are updated or reweighted by the reporting agency; the Census Bureau prior to 1997 or NASS from 1997 on. Where available, the updated or reweighted data were used; otherwise, the original reported values were used.
Changes in census item definitions and reporting as well as changes to county areas and names over the time span required a degree of manipulation on the data and county codes to make the data as comparable as possible over time. Not all of the census items are present for the entire 1950-2012 time span as certain items have been added since 1950 and when possible the items were derived from other items by subtracting or combining sub items. Specific changes and calculations are documented in the processing steps sections of this report. Other missing data occurs at the state and (or) county level due to census non-disclosure rules where small numbers of farms reporting an item have acres and (or) production values withheld to prevent identification of individual farms. In general, caution should be exercised when comparing current (2012) data with values reported in earlier censuses. While the 1974-2012 data are comparable, data prior to 1974 will have inflated farm counts and slightly inflated production amounts due to the differences in collection methods, primarily, the definition of a farm. Further discussion on comparability can be found the comparability section of the Supplemental Information element of this metadata report.
Excluded from the tabular data are the District of Columbia, Menominee County, Wisconsin, and the independent cities of Virginia with the exception of the three county-equivalent cities of Chesapeake City, Suffolk, and Virginia Beach. Data for independent cities of Virginia prior to 1959 have been included with their surrounding or adjacent county.
Please refer to the Supplemental Information element for information on terminology, the Census of Agriculture, the Inter-university Consortium for Political and Social Research (ICPSR), table and variable structure, data comparability, all farms and economic class 1-5 farms, item calculations, increase of farms from 1974 to 1978, missing data and exclusion explanations, 1978 crop irregularities, pastureland irregularities, county alignment, definitions, and references. In addition to the metadata is an excel workbook (VariableKey.xlsx) with spreadsheets containing key spreadsheets for items and variables by category and a spreadsheet noting the presence or absence of entire variable data by year.
Note: this dataset was updated on 2016-02-10 to populate omitted irrigation values for Miami-Dade County, Florida in 1997.
descript.purpose: Data tables were assembled from the Census of Agriculture to support regional and sub-regional studies of groundwater and surface-water quality by providing a historical (1950-2012) perspective of agricultural activities and trends on the land surface.
descript.supplinf:
Supplemental Information overview: This element contains information on the Census of Agriculture, and the Inter-university Consortium for Political and Social Research (ICPSR), table and variable structure, data comparability, all farms and economic class 1-5 farms, item calculations, increase of farms from 1974 to 1978, missing data and exclusions, 1978 crop irregularities, pastureland irregularities, county alignment, definitions, and references. In addition to the metadata is an excel workbook with spreadsheets containing key spreadsheets for items and variables by category and a spreadsheet noting the presence or absence of entire variable data by year.
Terminology: The structure in these files adheres to the following hierarchy: category, item, and variable; where category refers to a group such as land use, item refers to a specific land use such as "harvested cropland", and variable refers to the specific value such as acres of "harvested cropland".
Variable Reference Key: The file "VariableKey.xlsx" is an excel workbook consisting of table names, census items names, category units, and variable codes as well as a summarization of each census item and data year (please refer to worksheet "missing").
The Census of Agriculture: The census of agriculture is the leading source of facts and statistics about the Nations agricultural production. The census delineates aspects of agriculture such as the geographic distribution and differences by farm for such items as farm acreage, principal crops, and important kinds of livestock. It provides a detailed picture of U.S. farms and ranches every five years and is the only source of uniform, comprehensive, and comparable agricultural data for every state and county or county equivalent in the U.S. (NASS, 2014). For 156 years (1840 - 1996), the U.S. Census Bureau was responsible for collecting census of agriculture data. The 1997 Appropriations Act contained a provision that transferred the responsibility for the census of agriculture from the U.S. Census Bureau to the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA), National Agricultural Statistics Service (NASS). The first agriculture census was taken in 1840 as part of the sixth decennial census of population. The agriculture census continued to be taken as part of the decennial census through 1950. A separate mid-decade census of agriculture was conducted in 1925, 1935, and 1945. From 1954 to 1974, the census was taken for the years ending in "4" and "9". In 1976, Congress authorized the census of agriculture to be taken for 1978 and 1982 to adjust the data reference year so that it coincided with other economic censuses. This adjustment in timing established the agriculture census on a 5-year cycle collecting data for years ending in "2" and "7". The methodology that is used for the census has been mostly the same over its history, though it does undergo enhancements from census to census. A constant improvement of outreach and maintenance of a mailing list helps to enhance data reliability. Further, the U.S. Census Bureau and NASS relied on information from other government agencies, trade associations, producer associations, commerce data, veterinary lists, marketing associations, and a variety of other sources. Special commodity lists are also employed to address specific list deficiencies (NASS, 2004 Appendix C). Statistical methodologies are used to account for under-coverage, non-response, and misclassification. The uncertainty of agricultural values derived through these statistical techniques is quantified as a coefficient of variation (CV) and is published in the reports. The coefficient measures the reliability of an estimate, with a low CV suggesting a high reliability. The law which authorized the census of agriculture also prohibits publishing information that could be used to identify individual respondents. To ensure that confidentiality is maintained, all summarized data are checked prior to publication in a procedure called disclosure analysis. Disclosure analysis involves a review of each data table that have suppressed items that, if published, would reveal information about a respondent by derivation, that is, by adding or subtracting a published subtotal from a published total to reveal individual data. Since some tables included identical information arranged under several different classifications, the suppression of data in one table required the suppression of the same data in other tables. Detailed information regarding statistical and enumeration techniques can be found in the original census reports. Historical Census of Agriculture reports are available online as scanned documents from the Albert R. Mann Library, Cornell University. These documents range from 1925 through 1987. Census of Agriculture reports since 1992 can be found online at the USDA. Both of these sites are accessable from the url: www.agcensus.usda.gov/Publications/Historical_Publications/.
ICPSR: The Inter-university Consortium for Political and Social Research (ICPSR) provides access to an extensive collection of scientific data. The Michael Haines 2010 study, Historical, Demographic, Economic, and Social Data: The United States, 1790-2002 is a collection of over 100 datasets containing detailed county and state-level descriptive data. Parts 85-106 provide data from the United States Census of Agriculture for 1910 to 2002. The ICPSR data were employed to compile the historical tables for 1950 through 1992 and in a few cases 1997.
Data File Organization: Each table has [common] variables - "stfips" (the state FIPS code), "cofips" (the county FIPS code), "stcofips" (the formal county FIPS code), "Name" (name of state or county), and the variable "fYYYY000" (approximate land area in the state or county in the year YYYY -for each census year with data). Each file contains, where available, state totals along with the county values. State "cofips" equal "000". There is at least one tabular data file for each census item and in cases where there are 1969 and 1974 data for the economic classes 1-5, there are 2 files per item. There were two values reported for farms in 1969 and 1974 because the census for those years had a long form for major producers ($2,500 and greater) and a short form for small farms. In cases where data were available for both types of farms, separate tables were created to maintain the possibility of using either of the reported values. Tables that contain the economic class 1-5 farm values have the suffix 2500 such as "peanuts2500.txt" for example. These tables have different values for 1969 and 1974 only, the other years will be the same.
Variable structure: The selected items were chosen from six categories, (1) agricultural land use, (2) crop production, (3) farms and land in farms, (4) irrigation, (5) livestock inventory, and (6) fertilizer and manure use. The land-use category includes an inventory and acreage of farms, total cropland, harvested cropland, cropland in pasture, and other cropland (cropland idle or cropland in conservation practices). The crop category includes the major crop types grown within a region reported by the number of farms, acres harvested, and quantity harvested. The livestock category is an inventory of cattle, chickens, hogs, horses, sheep, and turkeys (some items include inventory of sales). The fertilizer and manure category contains fertilizer use including expenditures for fertilizer (1954-2012) and manure use (2002-2012. There are a total of 68 items and each item consists of at least three variables; approximate land area, numbers of farms reporting an item, and the number of acres. For crop items this would also include the amount of production. The variable naming convention used is an alpha-numeric code that denotes the category, the four-digit census year, and ends with a three-digit code specifying the variable. Prefix values are "a", "c", "f", "i", "l", and "n", where "a" is agricultural land use, "c" is crop production, "f" is farms, land in farms, and approximate land area, "i" is irrigation, "l" is livestock invetory, and "n" represents fertilizer and manure use. Thus, "a1950007" is the variable name for the number of farms reporting "total cropland" for a county in 1950 and "a1950008" is the variable name for the number of acres in "total cropland" for 1950, where "a" represents "agricultural land use", the code "007" represents number of farms reporting "total cropland", and the code "008" represents acres in "total cropland". Approximate land area in acres as reported for each census of agriculture is included with each variable for each census year to provide context of agricultural land within a county's land area as reported for that census year. Approximate land area is part of the farms category denoted by the prefix of "f" and has a suffix of "000", therefore f1950000, is the approximate land area for any given county in the year 1950.
Comparability: A major objective of the data tabulation and publication of the census publication program is to maintain a reasonable degree of comparability of agricultural data from census to census. This data collection is from 14 different censuses where definitions and data collection techniques may change over time and while the data are mostly comparable, a degree of caution should be exercised when using the data in analysis procedures. While the data are at a county-level resolution, a regional approach is more appropriate than a county-by-county analysis. Comparability of the data between censuses may be affected by such factors as the month in which the enumeration was made, the definition of a farm, or the wording of the survey. Data comparability will also be affected by changes in the price structure of the general economy, changes in the definitions of data concepts being measured, the introduction of new procedures for collecting and processing the data, and by methods adopted for estimating and (or) imputing data (U.S. Census Bureau, 1996). In general, processing steps and procedures were designed to develop reports that are as fully comparable as possible with reports of earlier censuses. When the comparability is affected to an appreciable extent, mention is made of the differences under the specific item in the definitions section of this "Supplemental Information" element. There are some limitations to take in consideration when comparing variables over time. These limitations include variability within items, inconsistencies in item definitions (variability over time), missing and withheld data (please refer to Census of Agriculture section in this Supplemental Information element), the regionality of the crop questionnaire, changes in livestock weight and (or) feed regimens.
All farms and economic class 1-5 farms: The outstanding factor affecting the overall distribution and comparability of the data over time is the change in the definition of a farm for the 1974 census. In general, the best comparability of historical to current (2012) data is from 1974 through 2012, in which the definition of a farm remained the same: an operation with sales of $1,000 or more. In years prior to 1974, data were collected for a more inclusive definition of a farm operation, that is any place with less than 10 acres and sales of $250 or more or any place with 10 or more acres that sold $50 or more of agricultural products. Emphasis was placed on obtaining more detailed information for those farms with annual sales of farm products of $2,500 or more ($1,000 or more for 1974 to present). The assumption for the time-series data is that the numbers of farms for the census years covering 1950-1969 are inflated or overestimated and the production, acreage, and livestock inventories are slightly inflated or overestimated. In other words, farm numbers decreased due to the definitional change, while production, acreage and livestock inventory numbers were affected to a much lesser extent. In 1964, economic class 1-5 farms made up 58 percent of the total farms and accounted for more than 96 percent of the total value of all farm products sold (U.S. Census Bureau, 1977 and 1981). Conversely, for the 1969 census, economic class 6 farms (those farms with annual sales of farm products less than $2,500) accounted for about 21% of total farms and less than 1% of total production. Production from these farms dropped to less than one-tenth of 1% of the total in the 1974 census (U.S. Census Bureau, 1977). In this dataset, files which have "2500" in the name hold values for economic class 1-5 farms for the years 1969-1974 only. For example, peanuts.txt contains data for "all farms" for the years 1950 through 1969, then data for farms with sales of $1,000 for the years 1974-2012. The file peanuts2500.txt contains data for "all farms" for the years 1950 through 1964, economic class 1-5 farms for 1969 and 1974, and farms with sales of $1,000 or more for 1978 through 2012. In some cases, only the values for economic class 1-5 farms are available, for example sugar beets. That is, the file sbeets2500.txt represents all farms for the years 1950-1964, economic class 1-5 farms for 1969 and 1974, and farms with sales of $1,000 or more for the years 1978-2012. Data for economic class 1-5 farms are not available for all items in 1969 or 1974. In cases where data for both types of farms were present, complete and separate tables were created to maintain the possibility of using either reported values.
All farms and economic class 1-5 farms (summary): 1950-1964: Data represent all farms. 1969: a) Data represent all farms, and b) Farms with sales of $2500 or more (some items). 1974: a) Farms with sales of $1,000 or more and b) Farms with sales of $2,500 or more(some items). 1978-2012: Farms with sales of $1,000 or more.
Cross-item calculations: In instances where a value has been determined by summing other variables or calculated using some other mathematical procedure, farm counts were excluded from the final table to avoid double counting as one farm may have reported values in any of the other categories used. Specific calculations can be found in the process step section of this report.
Increase in farms from 1974 to 1978: There are noticeable increases in farm counts due to the improved coverage of farms in the 1978 mail list. The increase of farm numbers and land in farm acreage observed in the 1978 census is a result of survey techniques, specifically the improved coverage of farms in the 1978 mailing list. Coverage evaluation studies for the 1974 census indicated that 10.7 percent of all farms were not included in the census. Farms missed in the census were small operations and accounted for less than 3 percent of the total value of agricultural products sold and less than 6 percent of the land in farms (U.S. Census Bureau, 1977). County-level data on acreages and inventories are generally comparable. Estimates of the net proportion of farms missed in the 1974 census varied widely by State, from a low of 0.7 percent in Nebraska to a high of 33.0 percent in West Virginia (U.S. Census Bureau, 1981). Overall, the percent of missed farms in 1974 compared to 1978 was greater where there are more small and part-time farms such as those in urbanized areas. The missed farms accounted for about 5 percent of the land in farms (U.S. Census Bureau, 1981).
Missing data and exclusions: Missing items are noted in the attribute definitions. Certain crop categories were extracted from ICPSR preliminary data, these data will have zero values for state totals and farm counts and are noted in the process steps. Excluded from the data are the District of Columbia, Menominee County, Wisconsin, and the independent cities of Virginia with the exception of the 3 county-equivalent cities of Chesapeake City, Suffolk, and Virginia Beach. Data for independent cities of Virginia prior to 1959 have been included with their surrounding or adjacent county according to the associations established by the Census Bureau for the 1959 census of agriculture.
1978 crop irregularities: Some 1978 crop data are missing values. Some counties will have data that match the reported numbers from the census, while others do not. For example, barley for grain; in Clayton county Iowa (FIPS 19043), the 1978 Census of Agriculture reports 6 farms, 158 acres, and 7,781 bushels, while the ICPSR data has 6 farms, zero acres, and 7,781 bushels. The majority of the 1978 county-level crop values checked agree with the reported numbers found in the 1978 census county crop tables. It is possible that these are the updated/re-weighted values that were to be reported alongside the 1982 values. State totals agree with the 1982 version of the 1978 values and not with the 1978 census report. However, this assumption cannot be verified due to the fact that the 1982 crop tables only include 1978 values for state totals and not individual counties.
Pasture irregularities: Census reports note that "cropland pastured" may be overstated due to the way farm operators filled out the questionnaire. The position of the question on the form may have caused farm operators to report other pasture categories under "cropland pastured" (U.S. Census Bureau, 1972, 1977). This anomaly does not affect "total pastureland", but may have some influence on the sub types of "total pastureland" ("cropland pastured", "woodland pastured" and "permanent pastureland") as well as "total cropland".
County alignment: Specific county codes and names have been reconfigured to align to current (2010) counties or county equvalent area, and in a few cases county data have been summed with another county to provide consistent or comparable units across time. The specifics of such manipulations are found in the process steps element of this report.
Definitions and explanations: The following definitions provide a description of some of the census items. These definitions are a compilation of the definitions found in the census reports, specifically the "definitions and explanation" appendixes for 1969-2012 or the "Introduction" for 1950-1964. Definitions relate only to those items that require an added level of description.
[Acres and quantity of crops harvested]. Crops were reported in whole acres, except for the following crops that were reported in tenths of acres: tobacco, nursery and greenhouse crops in the open, vegetables including potatoes and sweet potatoes, fruit and nut crops including land in orchards, and berries. Totals for crops reported in tenths of acres were rounded to whole acres at the aggregate level during the tabulation process. If two or more crops were harvested from the same land during the year (double cropping), the acres were counted for each crop and reported under the appropriate crop, but are only counted once for the land-use classification. Therefore, the total acres of all crops harvested generally exceed the acres of cropland harvested. An exception to this procedure was hay. When more than one cutting of hay was taken from the same acres, the acres were counted only once, but the quantity harvested includes all cuttings. Acreage cut and tons harvested for both dry hay and haylage, silage, or green chop was reported for each crop. For inter-planted crops or skip-row crops, acres were reported according to the portion of the field occupied, whether by a crop or whether it was idle land. If a crop was inter-planted in an orchard or vineyard and harvested, then the entire orchard or vineyard acreage was reported under the appropriate fruit crop and the inter-planted estimated crop acreage was reported under the appropriate crop. Acreage for orchards and short-rotation woody crops were included in cropland harvested whether the crop was harvested or not. Crops that were only hogged or grazed were reported as "cropland used only for pasture or grazing." Crop residue left in fields and later hogged or grazed was not reported as "cropland pasture", but as "harvested cropland".
[Approximate land area]. The approximate land area data were supplied by the U.S. Department of Commerce, U.S. Census Bureau. Area values may differ from prior censuses due to improved accuracy of spatial data, new measurements, construction of reservoirs, change in number and size of reservoirs, annexations, dis-incorporations, and other changes affecting county boundaries. The proportion of land area in farms may exceed 100-percent because some operations have land in two or more counties as acres are tabulated in the principal county of operation.
[Counties]. Excluded from the data are the District of Columbia, Menominee County, Wisconsin, and the independent cities of Virginia with the exception of the 3 county-equivalent cities of Chesapeake City, Suffolk, and Virginia Beach. The census of agriculture was not taken in the District of Columbia for 1959, but available data indicate few if any farms in that area. Data for Baltimore City, Maryland were combined with the data for Baltimore County and the data for St. Louis City, Missouri, were combined with those for St. Louis County. 1959 Agriculture census data for the independent cities in Virginia were enumerated, tabulated, and published with the data for adjacent counties.
[Cropland harvested]. This item includes land from which crops were harvested and hay was cut, land used to grow short-rotation woody crops, Christmas trees, orchards, groves, vineyards, berries, nurseries, and greenhouses. Land from which two or more crops were harvested was counted only once for the land-use classification. Land in tapped maple trees was included in woodland not pastured. Short-rotation woody crops were not explicitly referenced in the 1950-1997 census definitions, but were included as "Other nursery and greenhouse crops." Land in orchards that have been abandoned is part of idle cropland (other cropland). Mature crops hogged or grazed were considered to be crops harvested. Land used for other purposes either before or after the crops were harvested reported as "cropland harvested", without regard to the other uses.
[Cropland pastured]. This item includes land used only for pasture or grazing that could have been used for crops without additional improvement. Also included were acres of crops hogged or grazed before the crops reached maturity. However, cropland that was pastured before or after crops were harvested was included as harvested cropland rather than cropland for pasture or grazing. According to the 1969 and 1974 reports, this item may be overstated due to a tendency of farm operators to report pastureland in the first question relating to pastureland. The reports go on to say that obvious errors were corrected during data processing (U.S. Census Bureau, 1969 and 1974). Similarly, the 1950, 1954, 1959, and 1964 reports state that "permanent pasture" may have been reported either for this item or for "other pasture" depending on whether or not the enumerator or the farm operator considered it as cropland (U.S. Census Bureau, 1977).
[Farms]. The term "farms" represents the number of farms reporting an item.
[Farm definition]. The current census definition of a farm is any place from which $1,000 or more of agricultural products were produced and sold, or normally would have been sold, during the census year. The definition has changed nine times since it was established in 1850. The current (2012) definition was first used for the 1974 Census of Agriculture and has been used in each subsequent agriculture census.
[Fertilizer]. Includes farms with acres treated at least once with commercial fertilizer, lime, or soil conditioners. Data prior to 1987 do not include lime.
[Hay, all]. Data represent the area harvested with each acre counted only once if dry hay, haylage, grass silage, or green chop were cut from the same acreage or if there were multiple cuttings of dry hay, haylage, grass silage, or green chop. Data exclude corn silage and sorghum silage. Quantity produced is the sum of the quantity harvested of all hay including alfalfa, other tame, small grain, wild hay, and all haylage, grass silage and green chop after converting the all haylage, grass silage, and green chop quantity harvested to a dry equivalent basis (13-percent moisture). The green tons of all haylage, grass silage, and green chop harvested were multiplied by a factor of 0.4943 to convert to a dry equivalent. This conversion factor is based on the assumption that one ton of dry hay is 0.87 ton of dry matter, one ton of haylage or grass silage is 0.45 ton dry matter, and one ton of green chop is 0.25 ton dry matter. The all haylage, grass silage, and green chop quantity harvested is assumed to be comprised of 90-percent haylage and grass silage and 10-percent green chop. Therefore, the conversion factor used to adjust all haylage, grass silage, and green chop quantity harvested to a dry equivalent basis = ((0.45*0.9)+(0.25*0.1))/0.87 = 0.4943 (NASS, 2014). Prior to the 2002 census, green tons were converted to dry tons using a 3 to 1 ratio, where 3 tons of green material equals one ton of dry material (NASS, 1999). The census years from 1950 to 1964 did not report a "hay, all" category, the numbers in this data set are the sum of the individual hay categories. Therefore, for these census years, farms have been excluded and acres can be considered an overestimation as more than one harvest from the same acreage most likely occurred.
[Hay, all dry]. This category was introduced in the 2002 census. Data represent the area harvested with each acre counted only once if dry hay were cut from the same area.
[Hay, other tame]. Data represent acreage and dry tons of hay harvested from clover, fescue, lespedeza, timothy, Bermuda grass, Sudangrass, sorghum hay, and other types of legumes (excluding alfalfa) and tame grasses (excluding small grains).
[Hay, silage]. In this instance "silage" represents all green categories (Haylage, grass silage, and green chop). Data represent the acreage and quantity harvested of all types (alfalfa and all other). The quantity harvested was reported in green tons. If two or more cuttings of haylage, grass silage, or green chop were made from the same field, the acreage was reported as acres harvested in the appropriate haylage category only once, and the tonnage from all cuttings was combined in the corresponding quantity harvested. Straw acreage and production is excluded.
[Hay, wild]. Data represent acreage and dry tons of hay harvested that was predominantly wild or native grasses, even if it had some fill-in seeding of other grasses.
[Infrastructure (other land)]. This category includes land in house lots, barn lots, ponds, roads, ditches, and wasteland. It includes those acres in the farm operation not classified as cropland, pastureland, or woodland. This variable was often reported with the variable "Permanent pasture and rangeland, other than cropland and woodland pastured" as a sub category of "Other land".
[Irrigated land]. This category includes all land watered by any artificial or controlled means, such as sprinklers, flooding, furrows or ditches, sub-irrigation, and spreader dikes for agricultural purposes. Included are supplemental, partial, and pre-plant irrigation. Each acre was counted only once regardless of the number of times it was irrigated or harvested. If an operation reported less than one acre irrigated, the irrigated land for the operation was rounded to one acre. Livestock lagoon wastewater distributed by sprinkler or flood systems was also included.
[Land in farms]. The acreage designated as land in farms consists primarily of agricultural land used for crops, pasture, or grazing. It also includes woodland and wasteland not actually under cultivation or used for pasture or grazing, provided it was part of the farm operators total operation. Large acreages of woodland or wasteland held for nonagricultural purposes were excluded. All grazing land, except land used under government permits on a per-head basis, was included as land in farms provided it was part of a farm or ranch. The proportion of land area in farms may exceed 100-percent because some operations have land in two or more counties, but all acres are tabulated in the principal county of operation.
[Land in orchards]. This category includes land in bearing age and nonbearing age fruit trees, citrus or other groves, vineyards, and nut trees of all ages, including land on which all fruit crops failed. Excluded from this category are abandoned plantings and plantings of fewer than 20 total fruit, citrus, or nut trees or grapevines.
[Land in two or more counties]. With few exceptions, the land in each farm was tabulated as being in the operators principal county. The principal county was defined as the one where the largest value of agricultural products was raised or produced. It was usually the county containing all or the largest proportion of the land in the farm or viewed by the respondent as his/her principal county. Reports received showing land in more than one county were separated into two or more reports if the data would substantially distort county totals.
[Land used for vegetables]. Data are for the total land used for vegetable and melon crops. The acres were reported only once, even though two or more harvests of a vegetable or more than one vegetable were harvested from the same acres. This was a new category for the 1978 census, therefore the coverage of these data are only for the censuses beginning with the 1978 census through the 2012 census. This category includes farms and acres for potatoes and sweet potatoes for the 2007 and 2012 censuses.
[Nursery stock crops]. Data include ornamentals, shrubs, shade trees, flowering trees, evergreens, live Christmas trees, fruit and nut trees and plants, vines, palms, ornamental grasses, and bare root herbaceous perennials.
[Other cropland]. This includes all cropland other than harvested cropland or other pasture and grazing land that could have been used for crops without additional improvements. It includes cropland idle, cropland used for cover crops or soil improvement, cropland which all crops failed or were abandoned, cropland in cultivated summer fallow, and land planted in crops that were to be harvested after the census year. Prior to the 1959 census, this item fits the definition of "Cropland not harvested and not pastured", as "Other cropland" was a sub-category and did not include land used for soil-improvement crops.
[Other land]. Other land is the combination of two sub categories (1) infrastructure and (2) permanent pasture and rangeland, other than cropland and woodland pastured". See [Infrastructure] or [Permanent pasture (other land sub category)].
[Permanent pasture (other land sub category)]. This land-use category encompasses grazable land that does not qualify as woodland pasture or cropland pasture. It may be irrigated or dry land. In some areas, it can be a high quality pasture that could not be cropped without improvements. Also included acres of crops hogged or grazed but not harvested prior to grazing. However, cropland that was pastured before or after crops were harvested were included as harvested cropland rather than cropland for pasture or grazing. In other areas, it is barely able to be grazed and is only marginally better than wasteland. This variable is generally reported with the variable "Infrastructure" as a sub category of "Other land".
[Potatoes]. Potato acres are included in the vegetable acres for 2007 and 2012. Beginning with the 2007 census, potatoes were reclassified from individual crop numbers to "land used for vegetables" and "vegetables harvested for sale". Therefore, production was not collected for 2007 and 2012. Prior to 2007, potatoes were reported in the crops section with the number of farms, acres used, and quantity harvested reported in hundredweight.
[Sheep and lambs inventory]. Data for Western States (AZ, CA, CO, ID, MN, MT, NV, ND, OR, SD, UT, WA, WY) are for sheep and lambs of all ages owned regardless of location. Data for all other States are for sheep and lambs of all ages on the operation regardless of ownership. Sheep and lambs were collected in their own section to clarify to respondents when to report "owned" sheep and lambs versus any sheep and lambs on the operation.
[Short-rotation woody crops]. These crops grow from seed to a mature tree in 10 years or less. These are trees for use by the paper or pulp industry or as engineered wood. This does not include lumber. Acres in production were included in "Cropland harvested" in the land-use section of the report form.
[Sweet potatoes]. Sweet potato acres are included in the vegetable acres for 2007 and 2012. Beginning with the 2007 census, sweet potatoes were reclassified from individual crop numbers to "land used for vegetables" and "vegetables harvested for sale". Therefore, production was not collected for 2007 and 2012. Prior to 2007, sweet potatoes were reported in the crops section with the number of farms, acres used, and quantity harvested was reported in hundredweight.
[Total cropland]. This category includes cropland harvested, land in orchards, vineyards, nursery and greenhouse products, pasture and grazing land that could have been used for crops without additional improvements, cropland on which all crops failed or were abandoned, cropland in cultivated summer fallow, and cropland idle or used for cover crops or soil improvement but not harvested and not pastured or grazed. Acreage was not reported for census year 1959; only the number of farms were reported for "Total cropland". Acres were calculated by summing the cropland categories (cropland harvested, cropland used only for pasture, and cropland not harvested and not pastured). The 1974 census report notes that this item may be overstated for 1969 and 1974 due to a tendency of farm operators to report all pastureland in the first question relating to pastureland. It is further noted that obvious errors were corrected during processing.
[Turkeys]. Turkey data are a combination of turkeys for meat production, turkey hens and toms kept for breeding, and turkey brooders. Turkey brooders are immature birds sent to another farm for further "grow out" to meat production or breeding. This may result in a turkey being sold more than once from different operations. Turkeys were not enumerated on farms having less than $2,500 value of sales in 1969. This has little effect on the total production counted in the census, since essentially all of the turkeys are produced on economic class 1-5 farms (U.S. Census Bureau, 1972). The earlier category "turkeys raised" is equivalent to "turkeys sold" as noted in the 1969 report.
[Vegetables harvested for sale]. The acreage for vegetables harvested is the summation of the acres of individual vegetables harvested. All of the individual vegetable items may not be shown in the census reports. When more than one vegetable crop was harvested from the same acreage, acres were counted for each crop. This category includes farms and acres for potatoes and sweet potatoes for the 2007 and 2012 censuses.
[Wheat for grain]. Data were reported by type (Durum, winter, and spring other than Durum) for 1950-1974 and 1992-2012, however, for the census years 1978, 1982, and 1987 only total wheat was reported.
[Woodland pastured]. This item includes all woodland used for pasture or grazing during the census year. Woodland or forest land pastured under a per-head grazing permit was not counted as land in farms and, therefore, was not included in woodland pastured.
[Woodland, total]. This category includes natural or planted woodlots or timber tracts, cutover and deforested land with young growth which has or will have value for wood products and woodland pastured. Land covered by sagebrush or mesquite was reported as Permanent pastureland and rangeland or other land. Land planted for Christmas tree production and short rotation woody crops was reported in Cropland harvested, and land in tapped maple trees was reported as Woodland not pastured.

Although these data and associated metadata have been reviewed for accuracy and completeness and approved for release by the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS), no warranty expressed or implied is made regarding the display or utility of the data on any other system or for general or scientific purposes, nor shall the act of distribution constitute any such warranty.

attracc.attraccr: State and county values were spot cross-checked with census reports as tables were built. Basic scatter plots and a summary analysis revealed anomalies with certain values. All identified anomalies betwen ICPSR values and reported census values were addressed (please refer to process steps for specifics). A few variables from ICPSR in 1969 had abnormally large values, when checked, these outliers represent data that are withheld (D) to prevent the identification of an individual farm. These values were set to zero.

dataqual.complete:
Data set is considered complete for the information presented, as described in the abstract.
Typically, county-level data which are withheld due to census non-disclosure rules are included in state totals, however an a small number of cases state totals themselves are withheld. County data which have a positive value of farms for that iyem, but have a zero value for the commodity, may be assumed to be withheld. For example, if a county has 10 hog farms, but zero hogs, it is most likely that the number of hogs is withheld.
Calculated variables (cross-item calculations) will not contain the number of farms for that item. Some data in the census reports were not found in the ICPSR data sets. Michael Haines is in the process of addressing missing crop information (farm counts and State totals) for the 1969 and 1974 data. A summary of missing variables can be found in the missing data spreadsheet contained in the variable key document.

horizpa.horizpar: No formal positional accuracy tests were conducted.

vertacc.vertaccr: No formal positional accuracy tests were conducted.

procstep.procdesc: Census of Agriculture reports were assessed for each census year from 1950-2012 to develop an understanding of the census structure and the manner in which the data were collected and reported. This entailed a review of (1) methodology of data collection, processing, and reporting, (2) definitions and explanations of variables, and (3) any major changes that may affect consistency through the years. Reports for each year typically include supporting documents such as the census history, general explanation, survey methods, coverage evaluation, information sheets, report forms, and a guide to the census. In addition, there are regionalized survey forms that include crop sections to facilitate the reporting of the most important crops commonly grown within a report form region. A comprehensive list of variables was created and pared down by commonality of variables, comparability, and their potential impact to water quality. Categorical definitions were then examined for changes through time and a final list of desirable variables was determined with input from colleagues and other study groups.

Annexations and other changes affecting county boundaries over the time span required adjustments to the data. Counties that had split apart since 1950 were summed and the data were stored under the name of the original county. Yuma and La Paz counties, Arizona for example, were summed and attributed to Yuma County. Another type of jurisdictional change is when counties merge. In cases where this occurred, the earlier counties were summed to match the more current configuration. An example is the merger of Washabaugh county, SD and Jackson county, SD in 1983 under Jackson County. These two counties were summed and named Jackson County for the census years in this time series for 1982 and prior. Certain county changes cannot be rectified, either retroactively or proactively due to the scale of reporting. The spatial distribution of agricultural data within the county for every era is not known, so it cannot be proportioned spatially. Only counties that were manipulated are accounted for. An example to the exceptions of this procedure is Broomfield County, Colorado. Broomfield County was created in 2001 from parts of four counties and redistributing agricultural variables back to the four originating counties is beyond the scope of this project. Occurrences of these phenomena are noted in the specific process steps list. Omissions from the data are Menominee county, WI, independent cities of Virginia (excluding Chesapeake City, Suffolk, and Virginia Beach), Baltimore City, MD, and Washington D.C. Reported numbers of farms and agricultural activities for these areas are consistently low or withheld from reports for privacy reasons.

Each ICPSR data file was assessed for completeness of state-county FIPS codes and (or) other state-county code, variable data, variable names, variable units, and missing data. Enhancements and some fixes were then applied to each table as needed to produce a static ICPSR data set for each census year from 1950-1997 including data flags if available. Adjusted census year data sets were then created from the static data sets so that each county (land area unit) would be comparable over the 63 years covered by the 14 censuses. This was accomplished by updating FIPS codes and county or county equivalent names or in the cases where a county had split apart, summing the modern parts back into the original jurisdiction. The latter procedure was necessary due to the inability to proportion historical values spatially within a county. State and county-level census values were then extracted by variable from the adjusted data sets. At this point, variables were named. The variable naming convention is described in the Supplemental Information element.
Extracting on a variable-by-variable basis allowed for spot checks of data values for consistency with the published census reports. This method facilitated ease of cross-variable calculations if a variable was not reported but could be derived from other variables for a specific year. The final tables were then produced by merging each variable by census year so that each table represents an item and the values for each census year along with the reported approximate land area for that year. Alteration steps to the original data files and specific county adjustments can be found in the process steps list at the end of this section. Specific variable calculations are listed separately at the end of the process steps list. During the extraction of variables there were sometimes differences in the same variable for production values depending on the reporting year or agricultural region that had to be normalized. An example is the reporting of rice quantities. Census reports from 1950 to 1964 list values for the quantity of rice as bushels, 100-pound bags, or 162-pound barrels depending on the region reporting. The 2012 census reports quantities of rice by hundredweight, in this instance, quantities were converted to hundredweight. In cases where more than one item was involved in a calculation, the number of farms reporting was eliminated from the data file due to the fact that a single farm may have reported values in more than one of the items used in the calculation. An example of this is the item beef cows. Beef cows were not reported from 1950-1969, however beef cows and milk cows are sub types of the item "cows and heifers that have calved". For 1950-1969, the number beef cows were obtained by subtracting milk cows from "cows and heifers that have calved" and since farm counts cannot be determined; this variable was valued as zero because the numbers are not available.

NASS data: NASS’s Census Query Tool was used to extract data by variable for the census years 1997, 2002, 2007, and 2012. These data extractions were formatted to the variable structure described in the supplemental information section. The data were then adjusted by county to create the temporal data set by variable. Specific county adjustments are noted in the process steps for the NASS data.

The ICPSR 1950 data (data file: ag950co_final1) was initially altered by the following steps:
(1) Calculated missing data to zeros. (2) Changed variable "name" to proper case from all caps and stripped out historic names. (3) Created character variables "stfips", "cofips", and "stcofips" from numeric FIPS codes. (4) Dropped Alaska, District of Columbia, Independent cities (Virginia), and Yellowstone National Park observations. (5) Summed 24510 (Baltimore City) with 24005 (Baltimore County) under 24005 and dropped 24510. (6) Summed 29510 (St Louis City) with 29189 (St Louis County) under 29189 and dropped 29510. (7) Summed 46001 (Armstrong County) with 46041 (Dewey County) under 46041 and dropped 46001. (8) Summed 46131 (Washabaugh County) with 46071 (Jackson County) under 46071 and dropped 46131. (9) Summed 51055 (Elizabeth City, VA) and 51189 (Warwick county, VA) with 51199 (York county, VA) under 51199 and dropped 51055 and 51189. (10) Changed FIPS code 51123 (Nansemond County) to 51800 (Suffolk) and NAME to Suffolk. (11) Changed FIPS code 51129 (Norfolk County) to 51550 (Chesapeake City) and NAME to Chesapeake City. (12) Changed FIPS code 51151 (Princess Anne County) to 51810 (Virginia Beach) and NAME to Virginia Beach. (13) Changed FIPS code 32025 (Ormsby County) to 32510 (Carson City) and NAME to Carson City. (14) Changed FIPS code 12025 (Dade County) to 12086 (Miami-Dade County) and NAME to Miami-Dade.

1969 and 1974 Part 1.
The ICPSR data set "usag74_all_work" contained 1969 and 1974 data as well as both economic classifications of farm types (all farms and economic class 1-5 farms). This data set was missing specific crops necessary to this data collection. These crops were obtained from previous work files available from ICPSR (see part 2 of this process step for specifics about these data).

(3) Created character variables "stfips", "cofips", and "stcofips" from numeric FIPS codes. (4) Dropped Alaska, Hawaii, District of Columbia, Baltimore City, St Louis City, Menominee County, All Independent cities (Virginia), and All other counties observations. (5) Added missing counties (these were not reported or had data withheld). (6) Added flag variables if they were missing. (7) Changed data values of 40 billion, 4 billion, and 20 million to zero (these observations are withheld data). (8) Summed 46131 (Washabaugh County) with 46071 (Jackson County) under 46071 and dropped 46131. (9) Changed FIPS code 51510 (city of Alexandria) to 51810 Virginia Beach, ICPSR miscode. (10) Changed FIPS code 30113 (Yellowstone National Park) to 30111 Yellowstone County, ICPSR miscode. (11) Changed NAME from CHESAPEAKE to Chesapeake City. (12) Changed FIPS code 51123 (Nansemond County) to 51800 (Suffolk) and NAME to Suffolk. (13) Changed FIPS code 12025 (Dade County) to 12086 (Miami-Dade County) and NAME to Miami-Dade.

(7) Dropped Menominee County and "All other counties".

NASS 1997 and 2002 data from the 2002 report (census query tool retrievals by variable) were altered by the following steps:
(1) Retrieved each variable using NASS's census query tool and the "Export GIS" option (DBF table populated with FIPS codes). (2) Dropped Alaska, Hawaii, District of Columbia, and Menominee County observations. (3) Summed 04012 (La Paz County) with 04027 (Yuma County) under 04027 and dropped 04012. (4) Summed 35006 (Cibola County) with 35061 (Valencia County) under 35061 and dropped 35006. (5) Changed FIPS code 12025 (Dade County) to 12086 (Miami-Dade County) and renamed as Miami-Dade.

NASS 2002 and 2007 data from the 2007 report (census query tool retrievals by variable) were altered by the following steps:
(1) Retrieved each variable using NASS's census query tool and the "Export GIS" option (DBF table populated with FIPS codes). NASS 2007 and 2012 data from the 2012 report (census query tool retrievals by variable) were altered by the following steps:
(1) Retrieved each variable using NASS's census query tool and the "Export GIS" option (DBF table populated with FIPS codes). (2) Dropped Alaska, Hawaii, District of Columbia, Menominee County, and Broomfield County observations. (3) Summed 04012 (La Paz County) with 04027 (Yuma County) under 04027 and dropped 04012. (4) Summed 35006 (Cibola County) with 35061 (Valencia County) under 35061 and dropped 35006.

Variable changes The following adjustments were made to agricultural land-use (a) variables:
(1) "Total cropland" acres were not reported in the 1959 or 1964 census reports (only farm counts are reported), values were obtained from the sum of "cropland harvested", "cropland used only for pasture", and "cropland not harvested and not pastured". (2) "Other land, infrastructure" acres were mislabeled in the ICPSR 1964 data set as the number of farms, this was corrected. (3) "Total pasture and rangeland" acres were not reported for 1964-1974, acres were obtained from the sum of "cropland pastured", "woodland pastured", and "permanent pasture". (4) "Woodland not pastured" was not reported as an item in 1969 or 1974; acres were obtained by subtracting "woodland pastured" from "total woodland". (5) "Total woodland" acres were not reported in 1959 (only farm counts are reported), acres were obtained by the sum of "woodland pasture" and "woodland not pastured".

Variable changes The following adjustments were made to crop (c) variables:
(1) "Dry edible beans" in the 1964 ICPSR data set for California include values for "dry lima beans"; these were subtracted out and verified with the census reported values for California. (2) "Dry edible beans" were reported as pounds for 1954-1964 and again for 1978-1992, these values were converted to hundredweight. (3) "Hay, all" was introduced as an item in the 1969 census, prior to 1969 values were obtained by summing the sub items (quantity for green types were converted to dry equivalent tons). This procedure may artificially inflate acreage due to more than one harvest on the same land. (4) "Hay, other tame" was introduced as an item in 1978 as a summation of the other types. Values were obtained for 1969 and 1974 by the sum of "clover, timothy, and mixtures" with "coastal Bermuda" and "other hay". The years prior to 1969 are the sum of "clover", "lespedeza", "Bermuda", and "other hay". (5) The "Hay, silage" (haylage, silage, and greenchop) item did not exist in 1969 or 1974. Acreage and quantity for 1969 and 1974 is derived from the sum of "grass silage and haylage" with "hay crops cut and fed green". Quantity reported in the ICPSR data sets were in dry equivalent tons, these values were converted to green tons by multiplying by a factor of 3. Farm counts could not be calculated. This item counts acres only once if more than one harvest occurred on the same land, therefore, acres for these two years may be artificially inflated. (6) "Popcorn" quantities for 1950 through 1964 is reported as on ear pounds, whereas the later censuses report units in shelled pounds. Ear pounds were converted to shelled pounds by first converting to bushel weight and then converting to shelled pounds, where there are 70 pounds of popcorn on ear to a bushel and there are 56 pounds to a bushel of shelled pounds(USDA, 1992), specifically, (on ear pounds/70) * 56 = shelled pounds). (7) Potatoes (Irish potatoes) were reported in bushel units for 1950, 1954, and 1959. These values were converted to hundredweight based on 1 bushel equaling 60 pounds (USDA, 1992). (8) "Sweet potatoes" were reported in hundredweight in the 1974 ICPSR data. These values were multiplied by 100 and then divided by 55 to obtain bushel amounts, where a bushel equals 55 pounds (USDA, 1992). (9) "Rice" quantities were reported as thousands of pounds in the 1964 ICPSR data set, these units were converted to hundredweight (cwt). The 1950-1959 ICPSR quantities were reported as bushels, these units were converted to hundredweight (cwt), where 1 bushel of rice equals 45 pounds (USDA, 1992).

Variable changes The following adjustments were made to livestock (l) variables:
(1) "Beef cows" as an item was introduced in the 1969 census. Values for "beef cows" prior to this census were derived by subtracting "milk cows" from "cows and heifers that have calved". The 1969 & 1974 ICPSR data have some values that were greater than 40 million where the actual value had been withheld (D). These values were calculated as zero. (2) "Chickens on hand" (later changed to "layers and pullets 13 weeks old and older") was dropped from the census in 2002. A former sub item ("layers") was used as a replacement for "chickens" in the 2002, 2007, and 2012 tables and will therefore show an artificial decrease in numbers. (3) "Chickens sold" were not reported in the 1964 census, values were obtained by summing "broilers sold" with "hens and pullets of laying age sold". This logic is based on the categorization of 1954 and 1959 censuses, where "chickens sold" equal the sum of "broilers sold" and "other chickens sold". The 1978-1992 ICPSR data sets do not contain "all chickens sold", these values were obtained by summing "hens and pullets of laying age sold" with "pullets 3 months old or older not of laying age" (these were previously the two sub items of "chickens 3 months old or older"). Farm counts in both of these instances were set to zero because this process would most likely include the same farm more than once. (4) "Hogs and pigs" inventories in the 1969 & 1974 ICPSR data have several values that were greater than 40 million where the actual value had been withheld (D). These values were calculated as zero. (5) "Horses and ponies sold" did not appear as a item in the 1959 or 1964 censuses, the item "horses and mules" was substituted for these years. (6) "Sheep and lambs" inventories in the 1969 & 1974 ICPSR data have several values that were greater than 40 million where the actual value had been withheld (D). These values were calculated as zero.

Variable changes The following adjustments were made to nutrients (n) variables:
(1) "Commercial fertilizer" expenditures for 1954-1964 are reported in dollars, these values were converted to thousands of dollars.
